Massive push in Cork to improve road safety for pedestrians in joint campaign by four agencies
A multi-agency partnership between Cork-based groups launched a joint campaign prioritising pedestrian safety in high-risk zones.
Cork County Council - in partnership with An Garda S√≠och√°na, Cork County Fire Service and The Road Safety Authority (RSA) - is urging all road users to prioritise pedestrian safety in high-risk zones such as school gates throughout the year.
Speaking at the launch of the Pedestrian Safety Campaign, the Mayor of the County of Cork Councillor Mary Linehan-Foley highlighted the importance of working together to make communities safer.
‚ÄúWith the combined efforts of families, schools, residents, and drivers, County Cork can continue to strengthen its commitment to pedestrian safety.
‚ÄúEvery safe decision, whether it‚Äôs a driver slowing down, a parent modelling safe behaviour, or a child following the Safe Cross Code will contribute to safer roads,‚Äù Mayor Linehan Foley said.
The campaign offers advice to both drivers and pedestrians, such as the importance of using crossing points, managing the speed of cars and to drive responsibly, use the Safe Cross Code and wear high visibility clothing in dark conditions.
Pedestrians are remined to adhere to follow signals at controlled crossings, exercise caution at uncontrolled crossings where extra care is required and ensure traffic has come to a complete stop before stepping foot on the road.
Drivers are asked to slow down and obey posted speed limits, be aware of their surroundings and expect the unexpected ‚Äì especially where children are frequently located.
